1-s2.0-S0926860X14006875-si2.gif https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0926860X14006875/STRIPIN/image/gif/7062636586ce47b578ea74fec221c717/si2.gif https://s3.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-us-east/content/pii:S0926860X14006875/STRIPIN/image/gif/7062636586ce47b578ea74fec221c717/si2.gif si2 si2.gif gif 363 15 103 ALTIMG APCATA 15096 S0926-860X(14)00687-5 10.1016/j.apcata.2014.11.003 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 (a) Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of C-MoP and ball-milled MoPs, showing the peak broadening with milling time. (b) Stick pattern showing peak positions of C-MoP material. (c) Structure of MoP (molybdenum—blue; phosphorous—pink). Fig. 2 Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of MoP-G-11 and MoP-G-60-11. The average crystallite size of MoP was calculated using Scherrer's equation. Fig. 3 SEM images of (a) C-MoP, (b) MoP-60, (c) graphite and (d) MoP-G-60-11. Fig. 4 Cyclic voltammograms of (a) C-MoP and ball-milled MoP compounds, (b) MoP-graphite compounds in 0.5M H2SO4 solution at 50mV/s scan rate. Fig. 5 (a) Linear sweep voltammograms of MoP-G compounds compared with that of bare GCE, graphite and Pt/C and (b) Tafel slopes of MoP compounds versus Pt/C. Fig. 6 Nyquist plots of MoP-60 and MoP-G-60-11 catalysts in 0.5M H2SO4with overpotential of −0.35V. The inset shows the Nyquist plot of MoP-G-60-11. Note that the inset scale is in Ω while the main plot scale is in kΩ; the MoP-G-60-11 is clearly more conductive. Fig. 7 Gas chromatograms of MoP-G-60-11 electrode at (a) −0.45, (b) −0.5 and (c) −0.55V. Inset shows hydrogen generated bubbles during HER on catalyst coated carbon fiber paper. Fig. 8 (a) Linear sweep voltammograms at 2mV/s of MoP-G-60-11: first scan and recorded after 20h of continuous measurement and (b) amperometric analysis for a period of 20h at constant applied potential measured in sulfate buffer (pH=1) solution. Table 1 Average MoP crystallite size calculated using Scherrer's formula. Compound L α (nm) C-MoP 395.3 MoP-15 40.7 MoP-30 15.2 MoP-40 8.9 MoP-60 8.5 MoP-90 8.7 MoP-120 9.9 MoP-G-60-11 8.9 Table 2 BET surface areas of MoP and graphite compounds. Material BET surface area (m2/g) Graphite 9.6 C-MoP 1.8 MoP-40 15 MoP-60 25.1 MoP-90 5.3 MoP-120 4.3 MoP-G-11 7.6 MoP-G-60-11 68.2 Table 3 A summary of catalyst loading, Tafel slopes and exchange current densities of recently reported materials. Molybdenum phosphide-graphite nanomaterials for efficient electrocatalytic hydrogen production S.S. Jyothirmayee Aravind Kandalam Ramanujachary Amos Mugweru Timothy D. Vaden ⁎ Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Rowan University, 201 Mullica Hill Road, Glassboro, NJ 08028, USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +1-856-256-5457. Graphical abstract Clean hydrogen energy technology is an alternative to a fossil fuel-based energy economy. Efficient and economical catalysts are necessary for large-scale hydrogen generation. We report MoP and MoP-graphite nanosheets prepared by ball milling commercial compounds as efficient electrocatalytic materials for hydrogen generation via the hydrogen reduction mechanism. The hydrogen generated through electrochemical catalysis was evaluated using gas chromatography. The effects of ball milling time and proportions of MoP-graphite nanosheets on electrocatalytic activity were investigated. The new nanomaterials were characterized using powder XRD, SEM and BET surface area measurements. The results suggest superior electrocatalytic performance with a balance of ball-milled MoP and graphite. A Tafel slope of 63mV/dec was obtained for this new material. Keywords Molybdenum phosphide Graphite nanosheets Hydrogen evolution reaction Ball milling Electrochemical catalysts. 1 Introduction Electrocatalytic hydrogen generation is a promising area of research aimed to support the development of a robust hydrogen-based energy economy. Hydrogen can be generated via reduction of hydronium ions on electrode surface. This hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) requires a high overpotential. Currently, platinum-based catalysts offer the best performance for lowering the HER overpotential [1,2]. The high cost and low earth abundance of Pt and Pt group metals hinder their use and present an economic obstacle to widespread application. Therefore, significant research effort has been focused on finding cheap, efficient HER catalytic materials. Transition metal phosphides are important due to their advanced catalytic and electronic applications. Stinner et al. [3] investigated a series of transition metal phosphides for hydro-denitrogenation and found that MoP is an active catalyst for this application. Recently, it was established that most of the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) catalysts can be good HER catalysts as well. For instance, MoS2, a well-known HDS catalyst, was investigated for hydrogen evolution reaction. It was found that the HER activity of MoS2 stems from the more active edge sites rather than the stable basal planes [4]. Based on this fact, and the evaluation of HER activity by DFT on transition metal phosphides, Ni2P was identified as a good HER catalyst material [5]. The same group evaluated the HER activity of cobalt phosphide recently [6]. In contrast to the extensive research on sulfides, research on transition metal phosphide HER catalysis is relatively new. Several recent reports have demonstrated the electrocatalytic HER activity of molybdenum phosphide (MoP) materials [7–10]. In the present contribution, we report the effect of particle size and electrochemical synergy between molybdenum phosphide and graphite materials towards HER electrocatalysis. The effects of reduction in particle size in electrocatalytic applications especially in the fields of fuel cells have been investigated [11]. Improved performance due to reduced particle size has been observed due to the enhanced surface area and reactivity at the nanoscale [12]. Nanomaterials are increasingly utilized in the field of clean hydrogen energy technology. Silver nanoparticles coated on TiO2 nanosheet films are reported to exhibit improved photo-catalytic production of hydrogen than pure TiO2 nanosheet films [13]. Nanoclusters of Pt, Ru and Rh also exhibit high activities and also generate stoichiometric amount of hydrogen [14]. In order to be useful as an HER catalyst, bulk MoP materials must be doped and ground to reduce the size. In the current work, we utilize mechanical ball milling technique to reduce the MoP particle size and synthesize MoP nanoparticles for increased HER activity. In the process of ball milling, moving balls apply their kinetic energy to the material thereby breaking inter- and intra-particulate interactions and producing fresh surfaces by fracturing the material particles. The uncompensated bonds on the newly formed surfaces are normally chemically reactive. In the literature, ball milling has been reported as a mechano-chemical synthesis method for the production of unique nanostructures with new chemical properties. Large-scale synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon nanomaterials have been prepared by ball milling followed by annealing for electrochemical applications [15]. Wang et al. [16] utilized high energy ball milling to convert commercial microcrystalline MoS2 into distorted MoS2 nanostructures and report improved HER catalytic performance. Hence it is clear that reducing the particle size favorably affects the HER activity. A detailed characterization of MoP compounds along with their electrochemical studies is reported in the present work. Ball-milled MoP particles are at a risk of agglomeration due to high surface area. Incorporating high surface area materials such as graphite can help in the preparation of highly dispersed MoP nanoparticles. Graphite has garnered wide interest in the last few years due to its unusual combination of properties arising from the high degree of anisotropy that has been attributed to its hexagonal crystal structure. Graphite nanoparticles and nanosheets have been utilized as electrodes in lithium recharged batteries [17], adsorption substrates [18], and as a reinforcing material in nanocomposites [19], and they can be produced by chemical or mechanical methods. The most common experimental method to produce graphite nanosheets [20] or graphene nanoplatelets [21] is mechanical milling. The milling process brings about structural transformations in graphite and generates different defects [20], which can be exploited to anchor nanoparticles towards graphite planes. Ball milling has also been investigated as an alternative process to enhance the adhesion between Polyetherimide and exfoliated graphite nanoplatelets particles and also to reduce the particle size. High electrical conductivity and enhancement in modulus are achieved by this approach along with improved strength properties [22]. The performance of electrocatalytic materials can be further improved by the synergetic combination of electrocatalytic components, often by the use of carbon nanomaterials for superior conductivity and simplified substrate architecture. The electrical coupling between MoS2 nanoparticles and graphene is found to improve the electrocatalytic hydrogen production [23]. Recently, we have reported the combination of MoO2 and graphene as highly efficient HER catalytic material [24]. In the current work, we report the HER catalytic activity of new MoP-graphite nanocomposite materials prepared by ball milling. 2 Experimental Molybdenum phosphide (MoP, 99.5%) and graphite (crystalline, 300 mesh, 99%) were purchased from Alfa Aesar and used without further purification. Nanocrystalline molybdenum phosphide was prepared by ball milling the commercial MoP (referred to as C-MoP below) in a high-energy ball mill SPEX 8000M mixer/mill using tungsten carbide balls (10.74g). MoP samples were milled for different periods of 0, 15, 30, 40, 60, 90, and 120min to obtain samples labeled C-MoP, MoP-15, MoP-30, MoP-40, MoP-60, MoP-90, and MoP-120, respectively. In order to prevent compound overheating, a 15min time delay was provided at 15min intervals. We have termed the graphite after ball milling as graphite nanosheets, following the terminology employed previously for ball-milled graphite [20]. MoP-graphite nanosheets were prepared by mixing C-MoP and commercial graphite in different weight ratios in concentrated H2SO4 by stirring for nearly 1h and then washing with water several times until the pH was neutral. The material obtained after vacuum filtration was dried in air at 60°C overnight. The compounds obtained by mixing C-MoP and graphite in 1:1, 1:2, and 2:1 mass ratios are termed as MoP-G-11, MoP-G-12, and MoP-G-21, respectively. These compounds were then ball milled for 60min and labeled as MoP-G-60-11, MoP-G-60-12, and MoP-G-60-21. The MoP compounds were characterized with powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area analysis. The powder XRD of the materials were acquired with PANalytical Empyrean X-ray diffractometer after spreading the powder samples over glass slides and scanning with a 0.013° step size. The crystallite sizes were estimated with Scherrer's approximation [25]. SEM images were collected by a Leo Zeiss 1530 VP scanning electron microscope operated at 10kV. BET surface areas were obtained with a Quanta chrome instruments Nova 2200e Surface area and pore size analyzer. For the HER activity studies, 1.5mg of the catalyst was dispersed in 100μL of Nafion (prepared by mixing 1mL of 2wt% Nafion solution and 9mL of ethanol) by ultrasonication. Subsequently, 3μL of the slurry was drop-casted on a clean glassy carbon electrode (GCE, 0.07cm2 area). The modified GCE was allowed to dry under ambient conditions. Each modified electrode was fabricated with identical loading. Electrochemical characterization was performed using a CH Instruments 660C electrochemical work station using a standard three-electrode setup. The electrocatalytic activity of the materials was evaluated using both linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and cyclic voltammetry (CV). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurements were carried out using a similar three electrode system. The impedance spectra were recorded under a perturbation signal of 0.5V amplitude over a frequency range of 0.1Hz–1kHz. Gas chromatographic analysis of hydrogen evolved was carried out using Varian CP 3800 Gas chromatograph. The electrochemical cell was purged with nitrogen gas which also served as the carrier gas. The GC instrument was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a purge trap. For the GC experiments, another type of working electrode was prepared by coating 1mg/cm2 of material dispersed in Nafion solution over carbon fiber paper (Fuel Cell Stores) using a paint brush. All the measurements were carried out in 0.5M H2SO4 solution. 3 Results and discussion The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of C-MoP is shown in Fig. 1a. The stick pattern shows a perfect match with MoP with JCPDS No. 98-009-0157 (Fig. 1b). Molybdenum phosphide crystallizes in the hexagonal tungsten carbide (WC) structure in which each molybdenum atom is trigonal-prismatically surrounded by six phosphorus atoms, and vice versa (Fig. 1c). The MoP XRD pattern shows significant peak broadening and reduction in intensity with increased milling time. The diffraction peak broadening and intensity reduction in ball-milled powders are associated with the changes in crystallite size, lattice internal strain, and the instrumental effects [26]. We also characterized the mixed MoP-graphite materials before and after ball milling. We focus most of our analyses on the material prepared by mixing MoP and graphite in a 1:1 ratio (MoP-G-11). The XRD of MoP-G-11 (Fig. 2 ) before ball milling shows sharp peaks corresponding to C(002) crystalline reflections (2θ =26°) of graphite. After 60min of ball milling (to correspond with the “optimum” MoP-60 in Fig. 1), the sharp C(002) peaks are significantly reduced in intensity with increased width. The peak width is a probe of structural disorder: narrow peaks are an indication that sp2 clusters possess less defects and strain. Defect aggregation causes bond distortions at sp2C=C sites, thus in-plane sp2 bonds become strained and distorted and get converted to sp3 bonds and consequently sp2/sp3 carbon ratio decreases with the increase in lattice defects. These lattice distortions disturb the conjugation of double in-plane bonds and also the spacing of the sp2 carbon sites inducing microstructural and dimensional changes to the graphitic lattice. Thus the increase in width of the C(002) peak in MoP-G-60-11 in Fig. 2 indicates a decrease in overall crystallite size. This could be due to amorphitization of graphite via theC-C bond breaking. (1) L α = k λ β cos θ where L α is the average crystallite size, k =0.9, λ is the wavelength of Cu Kα radiation (1.54Å), β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM), and θ is the Bragg diffraction angle. The average crystallite sizes of MoP compounds based on Eq. (1) are given in Table 1 . The effectiveness of the milling process to deform the compound is evident from the large changes to crystallite thickness after the samples were milled for only a short period of time. It is also notable from Table 1 that the average sizes of the MoP-60 nanomaterial and the MoP-G-60-11 material are very similar. This indicates that the decrease in size by ball milling is the same regardless of the presence or absence of graphite in the sample. Fig. 3 shows the SEM images of MoP, graphite, and MoP-G compounds. Large MoP particles are observed with C-MoP before ball milling (Fig. 3a), while after 60-min ball milling (Fig. 3b) the particle sizes are clearly smaller. Thus, ball milling produces sub-micron agglomerates that corroborate the observations of the reduced crystallite size from the XRD results of milled MoP compared to C-MoP. Similar results are obtained for the graphite-containing materials. The SEM image of commercial graphite shows thick micrometer-sized flakes (Fig. 3c). On the other hand, the SEM image of MoP-G-60-11 shows a reduced size for graphite flakes along with nanoparticles of MoP dispersed on graphite nanosheets (Fig. 3d). The BET surface areas of different MoP samples are summarized in Table 2 . The ball milling of MoP initially results in an increased surface area. For example, BET surface areas of MoP-40 and MoP-60 are 15 and and 25m2/g, respectively. With further increase in milling time, the BET surface area decreases, which could be due to the agglomeration of nanoparticles. The lowest value, 4.3m2/g, is obtained for the MoP-120 (sample obtained by 120min of ball milling). This shows that a variation of 1h of milling time (from 60 to 120min) diminishes the surface area by nearly 6%. This is in agreement with previous observations that the specific surface area decreases as a function of milling time, and hence milling time control is crucial to obtain the desired specific surface area [27]. The C-MoP has a surface area of 1.8m2/g, in agreement with the reported literature value of 2m2/g [3]. On the otherhand, the surface areas of MoP-G-11 before and after milling are 7.6 and 68, respectively. Hence, a nearly 9-fold enhancement in surface area corroborates the reduced crystallite size measurements from XRD. By comparing Tables 1 and 2, it is clear that the decrease in crystallite size coincides roughly with the increase in the BET specific surface area. We have also evaluated the electrochemical activity of the MoP compounds for HER. The CV results for MoP compounds and MoP-graphite compounds, recorded at 50mV/s, are shown in Fig. 4 . For both sets of data, the results demonstrate an increased current response for ball-milled compounds relative to those without milling. The results show that the MoP-60 provides the highest current while the commercial MoP provides the lowest current. The current density measurements yield a clear trend that activity increases with ball milling time up to 60min. This trend in electrochemical activity is consistent with the trends in surface areas and particle sizes. Compared to MoP-60 (Fig. 4a), MoP-G compounds after ball milling (Fig. 4b) show better current responses. The highest current and lowest potential window of MoP-G-60-11 is indicative of its superior catalytic activity over other MoP-G compounds. Fig. 5a shows the polarization curves of coated electrodes. Polarization studies were carried out on Pt/C (10wt% loading of Pt on Vulcan carbon) as a reference point. The bare GCE does not show any activity for H2 production. However, for the 60-min ball-milled compound (MoP-60), the catalytic current is observed at a low onset reduction potential of about −0.32V (vs. Ag/AgCl). Above −0.32V, the cathodic current rises rapidly at more negative potentials with considerable current density of 9mA/cm2 at 500mV overpotential. Commercial MoP coated electrodes display much lower HER activities, with a current density of only 0.9mA/cm2 at 500mV (Fig. S1). This is 10 times lower than the MoP-60 modified GCE. The current density of graphite is 0.07mA/cm2 at 500mV, which is much lower than that commercial MoP. Similarly, other ball-milled MoP compounds (except MoP-40) exhibit lower current densities at 500mV (Fig. S1). The commercial and ball-milled MoP BET surface area analyses (Table 2) show an increase in surface area with up to 60min of milling time and a decline with longer times. There is a correlation between the surface area and electrocatalytic activity, indicating that the surface area is a significant parameter dominating the HER, as reported extensively in the literature [28]. The increase in surface area of the electrode with reduced particle size in turn leads to large contact area between electrolyte and electrode. This enlargement of electrode area would also help improved performance of milled samples [29]. However, the catalytic current densities obtained from MoP-G compounds are higher than that of the MoP-60 compound. Among the three different MoP-G composites, the one with 1:1 mixing of C-MoP and graphite stands out with lower onset reduction potential and higher current density. The onset reduction potentials with Pt/C, MoP-G-60-11, MoP-G-60-12, and MoP-G-60-21 are respectively −277, −460, −486, and −478mV at 10mA/cm2 current density. Because of the high surface energy resulting from the dangling bonds produced during ball milling, MoP nanoparticles could have a tendency to agglomerate. The existence of conducting graphite can prevent aggregation and also enhance the electron transport by acting as a conducting substrate. This implies that conductivity was another factor influencing the HER catalysis. Based on the above factors, it can be concluded that the improved catalytic activity of the MoP-G-60 compound modified GCE results from a right combination of specific structural properties, such as large surface area, which in turn leads to more catalytically active sites and less particle aggregation. To obtain further insight into the HER on various MoP catalysts, we performed Tafel analysis from the linear-sweep voltammetry data. Tafel plots of various catalyst materials were formulated from the polarization curves and are shown in Fig. 5b. The linear region of Tafel plots were fitted into the Tafel equation: (2) η = b log j + a where η (mV) represents the applied overpotential, b (mV/dec) is the Tafel slope and j (mA/cm2) is the resulting (measured) current density, and a (mV) is the intercept related to the exchange current density j 0 (mA/cm2). The resulting Tafel slopes of MoP-60, MoP-G-12, MoP-G-21, MoP-G-11, and Pt/C are respectively 85, 82, 69, 63, and 35mV/dec. The smaller Tafel slope for MoP-G-60-11 compared to MoP-60 may be explained by the fact that more accessible catalytically active edges are created in MoP-G-60-11 because of the incorporation of conducting graphite nanoplatelets. This view was further corroborated by the larger BET surface area of the MoP-G-60-11 (68m2/g) in comparison to MoP-60 (25m2/g), since higher surface area of the MoP-graphite nanosheets can result in a higher density of accessible reactive sites. The Tafel slope of 63mV/dec is close to other recently reported molybdenum-based HER evolution catalysts, such as Mo2C/carbon nanotubes (55mV/dec), core/shell MoO3-MoS2 nanowires (about 50–60mV/dec), and MoS2 crystals (55–60mV/dec) [30]. The Tafel slope is also close to recently reported MoP catalysts while the exchange current is higher that most materials reported. For instance, Chen et al. [9] reported a Tafel slope of 60mV/dec with pure MoP. Also, MoP prepared by temperature programmed reduction technique exhibits a Tafel slope of 54mV/dec [10]. McEnaney et al. [8] reported amorphous molybdenum phosphide nanoparticles for hydrogen production. With MoP nanoparticles coated over Ti foil, they reported a Tafel slope of 45mV/dec. Table 3 gives a direct comparison between HER catalytic activities of reported MoP catalysts with the present MoP-G-60-11 nanomaterial catalyst. The enhanced HER activity with the MoP-G materials could be attributed to the improved electrical conductivity compared to bare MoP-60 because the presence of graphite induces fast electron transport from the less conductive MoP nanoparticles to the electrode. To investigate this hypothesis, we performed AC impedance analyses. Fig. 6 compares the AC impedance spectra of the MoP-60 and MoP-G-60-11 composites. Note that the plot axes units are kΩ, while the inset units are Ω. It is clearly observed from Fig. 6 that the MoP-G-60-11 (inset) compound has a smaller radius of semicircle than MoP-60 in the Nyquist plots, implying lower charge-transfer impedance and thus more facile electrode kinetics [31]. The catalyst prepared by mixing and ball milling MoP and pure graphite (MoP-G-60-11) was investigated for H2 production. Hydrogen gas produced with MoP-G-60-11, was collected and evaluated using gas chromatography with thermal conductivity detection. Hydrogen gas generated at the electrode (inset photo) was collected over the solution and injected onto a special hydrogen column. As shown in Fig. 7 , with more applied potential, the reaction rate increases and hence the amount of hydrogen evolved increases. Note that hydrogen gas starts evolving at −0.35V applied potential, but is not detectable until −0.45V is applied. We also evaluated the stability of the MoP-G-60-11 catalyst in acidic solution using material coated on glassy carbon electrode. In Fig. 8a, linear sweep voltammograms of the material coated onto a glassy carbon electrode are shown before and after 20h of continuous operation. Fig. 8b shows the amperometric curve recorded at a constant applied potential during the 20h of operation. It is observed that the cathodic current decay is negligible even over 20h, indicating a good stability of this material for long-time hydrogen production under strongly acidic conditions. Indeed, Fig. 8a suggests slightly improved activity after 20h, confirming the high electrocatalytic material stability and reproducibility. 4 Conclusions We have demonstrated the electrocatalytic activity of the ball-milled MoP and MoP-graphite for the production of hydrogen. XRD and SEM measurements show a reduction in MoP size with ball milling time up to 1h of milling of MoP with an enhanced BET surface area, after ball milling. The electrocatalytic performance of the MoP improves with decreased particle size. After 1h of milling, the particle sizes increase, likely due to agglomeration. With the incorporation of graphite to MoP, the onset reduction potential for hydrogen production decreases and the current density increases. We attribute the improved electrocatalytic activity of MoP-G compound to a better dispersion of MoP nanoparticles over high surface area graphite which in turn possesses more active sites and also to the improved electron transfer brought about by conducting graphite. The evolved hydrogen gas was characterized using gas chromatograms at different applied voltages. The stability measurements show that the MoP-graphite is highly stable under continuous as well as repeated operation, which is highly desirable for an efficient HER catalyst material. This study offers a new method for the development of highly active non-noble electrocatalysts by simple solid state ball milling for hydrogen production from water splitting. Acknowledgment This work was supported by a research grant from NATCO Pharmaceuticals, Hyderabad, India. coredata.dc:description: Clean hydrogen energy technology is an alternative to a fossil fuel-based energy economy. Efficient and economical catalysts are necessary for large-scale hydrogen generation. We report MoP and MoP-graphite nanosheets prepared by ball milling commercial compounds as efficient electrocatalytic materials for hydrogen generation via the hydrogen reduction mechanism. The hydrogen generated through electrochemical catalysis was evaluated using gas chromatography. The effects of ball milling time and proportions of MoP-graphite nanosheets on electrocatalytic activity were investigated. The new nanomaterials were characterized using powder XRD, SEM and BET surface area measurements. The results suggest superior electrocatalytic performance with a balance of ball-milled MoP and graphite. A Tafel slope of 63mV/dec was obtained for this new material.
coredata.dc:title: Molybdenum phosphide-graphite nanomaterials for efficient electrocatalytic hydrogen production
